answer_html: \(P\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 2/5\\ 2/5\\ 1/5 \end{bmatrix}.\) Therefore we get that the probability of being in state 3 is 1/5.Notice that the output probabilities sum to 1.This is a requirement since we only allow transitions from states 1 to 3, this summation to 1 simply says that no matter where we start we will end up somewhere in states 1 to 3.

$P\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix}
2/5\\
2/5\\
1/5
\end{bmatrix}.$ Therefore we get that \textbf{the probability of being in state 3 is
1/5}.Notice that the output probabilities sum to 1.This is a
requirement since we only allow transitions from states 1 to 3, this
summation to 1 simply says that no matter where we start we will end up
somewhere in states 1 to 3.
hints_html: Recall that a transition matrix with element i,j (row i and column j) is the probability of reaching state i coming from state j. The vector input is the initial states and the vector output is the final states.
hints_latex:
Recall that a transition matrix with element i,j (row i and column j) is
the probability of reaching state i coming from state j. The vector
input is the initial states and the vector output is the final states.
hints_raw: Recall that a transition matrix with element i,j (row i and column j) is the probability of reaching state i coming from state j.  The vector input is the initial states and the vector output is the final states.
question: A 22
sols_html:
If the transition matrix is

\[\begin{aligned} P=\begin{bmatrix} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10\\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10\\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

then the operation Px=b gives us the probability of being in each of the three states b based on where we started, x. We are told that we are equally likely to be in any of the three states so we have as our vector,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}=\left[1/3,1/3,1/3\right].\end{aligned}\]

To find out the probabilities of being in each state after one transition we compute Px,

\[\begin{aligned} P\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10\\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10\\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/3\\ 1/3\\ 1/3 \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} 2/5\\ 2/5\\ 1/5 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we get that the probability of being in state 3 is 1/5. Notice that the output probabilities sum to 1. This is a requirement since we only allow transitions from states 1 to 3, this summation to 1 simply says that no matter where we start we will end up somewhere in states 1 to 3.
sols_raw:
If the transition matrix is

:<math>
P=\begin{bmatrix}
8/10  &  3/10  &  1/10\\
2/10  &  3/10  &  7/10\\
0  &  4/10  &  2/10
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

then the operation P'''x'''='''b''' gives us the probability of being in each of the three states '''b''' based on where we started, '''x'''.  We are told that we are equally likely to be in any of the three states so we have as our vector,

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=\left[1/3,1/3,1/3\right].
</math>

To find out the probabilities of being in each state after one transition we compute P'''x''',

:<math>
P\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix}
8/10  &  3/10  &  1/10\\
2/10  &  3/10  &  7/10\\
0  &  4/10  &  2/10
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1/3\\
1/3\\
1/3
\end{bmatrix}
=\begin{bmatrix}
2/5\\
2/5\\
1/5
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Therefore we get that '''the probability of being in state 3 is 1/5'''.  Notice that the output probabilities sum to 1.  This is a requirement since we only allow transitions from states 1 to 3, this summation to 1 simply says that no matter where we start we will end up somewhere in states 1 to 3.
statement_html:
Questions A22-A24 concern a random walk with three states that has transition matrix

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{c c c} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10 \\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10 \\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

If the walker is equally likely to start in each of the three states, what is the chance that she will be in state 3 at the next time step?
statement_latex:
Questions A22-A24 concern a random walk with three states that has
transition matrix

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{c c c} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10 \\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10 \\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

If the walker is equally likely to start in each of the three states,
what is the chance that she will be in state 3 at the next time step?
statement_raw:

</math>

If the walker is equally likely to start in each of the three states, what is the chance that she will be in state 3 at the next time step?
